Do not crave his delicacies,
    for that food is deceptive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not wear yourself out to get rich;
    do not trust your own cleverness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cast but a glance at riches, and they are gone,
    for they will surely sprout wings
    and fly off to the sky like an eagle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not eat the food of a stingy host,
    do not crave his delicacies;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for he is the kind of person
    who is always thinking about the cost.
‘Eat and drink,’ he says to you,
    but his heart is not with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will vomit up the little you have eaten
    and will have wasted your compliments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not speak to fools,
    for they will scorn your prudent words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not move an ancient boundary stone
    or encroach on the fields of the fatherless,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for their Defender is strong;
    he will take up their case against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Apply your heart to instruction
    and your ears to words of knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not withhold discipline from a child;
    if you punish them with the rod, they will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Punish them with the rod
    and save them from death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, if your heart is wise,
    then my heart will be glad indeed;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
my inmost being will rejoice
    when your lips speak what is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not let your heart envy sinners,
    but always be zealous for the fear of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is surely a future hope for you,
    and your hope will not be cut off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, my son, and be wise,
    and set your heart on the right path:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
do not join those who drink too much wine
    or gorge themselves on meat,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for drunkards and gluttons become poor,
    and drowsiness clothes them in rags.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to your father, who gave you life,
    and do not despise your mother when she is old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Buy the truth and do not sell it –
    wisdom, instruction and insight as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The father of a righteous child has great joy;
    a man who fathers a wise son rejoices in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May your father and mother rejoice;
    may she who gave you birth be joyful!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, give me your heart
    and let your eyes delight in my ways,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for an adulterous woman is a deep pit,
    and a wayward wife is a narrow well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a bandit she lies in wait
    and multiplies the unfaithful among men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has woe? Who has sorrow?
    Who has strife? Who has complaints?
    Who has needless bruises? Who has bloodshot eyes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who linger over wine,
    who go to sample bowls of mixed wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not gaze at wine when it is red,
    when it sparkles in the cup,
    when it goes down smoothly!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the end it bites like a snake
    and poisons like a viper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your eyes will see strange sights,
    and your mind will imagine confusing things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be like one sleeping on the high seas,
    lying on top of the rigging.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘They hit me,’ you will say, ‘but I’m not hurt!
    They beat me, but I don’t feel it!
When will I wake up
    so I can find another drink?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not envy the wicked,
    do not desire their company;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for their hearts plot violence,
    and their lips talk about making trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By wisdom a house is built,
    and through understanding it is established;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
through knowledge its rooms are filled
    with rare and beautiful treasures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wise prevail through great power,
    and those who have knowledge muster their strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely you need guidance to wage war,
    and victory is won through many advisors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom is too high for fools;
    in the assembly at the gate they must not open their mouths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever plots evil
    will be known as a schemer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The schemes of folly are sin,
    and people detest a mocker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you falter in a time of trouble,
    how small is your strength!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Rescue those being led away to death;
    hold back those staggering towards slaughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you say, ‘But we knew nothing about this,’
    does not he who weighs the heart perceive it?
Does not he who guards your life know it?
    Will he not repay everyone according to what they have done?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eat honey, my son, for it is good;
    honey from the comb is sweet to your taste.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not lurk like a thief near the house of the righteous,
    do not plunder their dwelling-place;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for though the righteous fall seven times, they rise again,
    but the wicked stumble when calamity strikes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not gloat when your enemy falls;
    when they stumble, do not let your heart rejoice,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
or the Lord will see and disapprove
    and turn his wrath away from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not fret because of evildoers
    or be envious of the wicked,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for the evildoer has no future hope,
    and the lamp of the wicked will be snuffed out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fear the Lord and the king, my son,
    and do not join with rebellious officials,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for those two will send sudden destruction on them,
    and who knows what calamities they can bring?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These also are sayings of the wise:
To show partiality in judging is not good:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
whoever says to the guilty, ‘You are innocent,’
    will be cursed by peoples and denounced by nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But it will go well with those who convict the guilty,
    and rich blessing will come on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An honest answer
    is like a kiss on the lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not testify against your neighbour without cause –
    would you use your lips to mislead?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not say, ‘I’ll do to them as they have done to me;
    I’ll pay them back for what they did.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I went past the field of a sluggard,
    past the vineyard of someone who has no sense;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
thorns had come up everywhere,
    the ground was covered with weeds,
    and the stone wall was in ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I applied my heart to what I observed
    and learned a lesson from what I saw:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a little sleep, a little slumber,
    a little folding of the hands to rest –
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and poverty will come on you like a thief
    and scarcity like an armed man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are more proverbs of Solomon, compiled by the men of Hezekiah king of Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is the glory of God to conceal a matter;
    to search out a matter is the glory of kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the heavens are high and the earth is deep,
    so the hearts of kings are unsearchable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remove the dross from the silver,
    and a silversmith can produce a vessel;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
remove wicked officials from the king’s presence,
    and his throne will be established through righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not exalt yourself in the king’s presence,
    and do not claim a place among his great men;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
it is better for him to say to you, ‘Come up here,’
    than for him to humiliate you before his nobles.
What you have seen with your eyes
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
do not bring hastily to court,
for what will you do in the end
    if your neighbour puts you to shame?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you take your neighbour to court,
    do not betray another’s confidence,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
or the one who hears it may shame you
    and the charge against you will stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like apples of gold in settings of silver
    is a ruling rightly given.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like an earring of gold or an ornament of fine gold
    is the rebuke of a wise judge to a listening ear.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Like clouds and wind without rain
    is one who boasts of gifts never given.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Through patience a ruler can be persuaded,
    and a gentle tongue can break a bone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you find honey, eat just enough –
    too much of it, and you will vomit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Seldom set foot in your neighbour’s house –
    too much of you, and they will hate you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a club or a sword or a sharp arrow
    is one who gives false testimony against a neighbour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a broken tooth or a lame foot
    is reliance on the unfaithful in a time of trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like one who takes away a garment on a cold day,
    or like vinegar poured on a wound,
    is one who sings songs to a heavy heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat;
    if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In doing this, you will heap burning coals on his head,
    and the Lord will reward you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a north wind that brings unexpected rain
    is a sly tongue – which provokes a horrified look.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better to live on a corner of the roof
    than share a house with a quarrelsome wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like cold water to a weary soul
    is good news from a distant land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a muddied spring or a polluted well
    are the righteous who give way to the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is not good to eat too much honey,
    nor is it honourable to search out matters that are too deep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a city whose walls are broken through
    is a person who lacks self-control.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like snow in summer or rain in harvest,
    honour is not fitting for a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a fluttering sparrow or a darting swallow,
    an undeserved curse does not come to rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,
    and a rod for the backs of fools!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not answer a fool according to his folly,
    or you yourself will be just like him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Answer a fool according to his folly,
    or he will be wise in his own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sending a message by the hands of a fool
    is like cutting off one’s feet or drinking poison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like the useless legs of one who is lame
    is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like tying a stone in a sling
    is the giving of honour to a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a thorn-bush in a drunkard’s hand
    is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like an archer who wounds at random
    is one who hires a fool or any passer-by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a dog returns to its vomit,
    so fools repeat their folly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you see a person wise in their own eyes?
    There is more hope for a fool than for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sluggard says, ‘There’s a lion in the road,
    a fierce lion roaming the streets!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a door turns on its hinges,
    so a sluggard turns on his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sluggard buries his hand in the dish;
    he is too lazy to bring it back to his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sluggard is wiser in his own eyes
    than seven people who answer discreetly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like one who grabs a stray dog by the ears
    is someone who rushes into a quarrel not their own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a maniac shooting
    flaming arrows of death
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
is one who deceives their neighbour
    and says, ‘I was only joking!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Without wood a fire goes out;
    without a gossip a quarrel dies down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As charcoal to embers and as wood to fire,
    so is a quarrelsome person for kindling strife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The words of a gossip are like choice morsels;
    they go down to the inmost parts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a coating of silver dross on earthenware
    are fervent lips with an evil heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Enemies disguise themselves with their lips,
    but in their hearts they harbour deceit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though their speech is charming, do not believe them,
    for seven abominations fill their hearts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their malice may be concealed by deception,
    but their wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it;
    if someone rolls a stone, it will roll back on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A lying tongue hates those it hurts,
    and a flattering mouth works ruin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not boast about tomorrow,
    for you do not know what a day may bring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let someone else praise you, and not your own mouth;
    an outsider, and not your own lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Stone is heavy and sand a burden,
    but a fool’s provocation is heavier than both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Anger is cruel and fury overwhelming,
    but who can stand before jealousy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better is open rebuke
    than hidden love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wounds from a friend can be trusted,
    but an enemy multiplies kisses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One who is full loathes honey from the comb,
    but to the hungry even what is bitter tastes sweet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a bird that flees its nest
    is anyone who flees from home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Perfume and incense bring joy to the heart,
    and the pleasantness of a friend
    springs from their heartfelt advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not forsake your friend or a friend of your family,
    and do not go to your relative’s house when disaster strikes you –
    better a neighbour nearby than a relative far away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart;
    then I can answer anyone who treats me with contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The prudent see danger and take refuge,
    but the simple keep going and pay the penalty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take the garment of one who puts up security for a stranger;
    hold it in pledge if it is done for an outsider.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If anyone loudly blesses their neighbour early in the morning,
    it will be taken as a curse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A quarrelsome wife is like the dripping
    of a leaky roof in a rainstorm;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
restraining her is like restraining the wind
    or grasping oil with the hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As iron sharpens iron,
    so one person sharpens another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The one who guards a fig-tree will eat its fruit,
    and whoever protects their master will be honoured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As water reflects the face,
    so one’s life reflects the heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Death and Destruction are never satisfied,
    and neither are human eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The crucible for silver and the furnace for gold,
    but people are tested by their praise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though you grind a fool in a mortar,
    grinding them like grain with a pestle,
    you will not remove their folly from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be sure you know the condition of your flocks,
    give careful attention to your herds;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for riches do not endure for ever,
    and a crown is not secure for all generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the hay is removed and new growth appears
    and the grass from the hills is gathered in,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the lambs will provide you with clothing,
    and the goats with the price of a field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will have plenty of goats’ milk to feed your family
    and to nourish your female servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked flee though no one pursues,
    but the righteous are as bold as a lion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When a country is rebellious, it has many rulers,
    but a ruler with discernment and knowledge maintains order.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A ruler who oppresses the poor
    is like driving rain that leaves no crops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who forsake instruction praise the wicked,
    but those who heed it resist them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Evildoers do not understand what is right,
    but those who seek the Lord understand it fully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better the poor whose way of life is blameless
    than the rich whose ways are perverse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A discerning son heeds instruction,
    but a companion of gluttons disgraces his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever increases wealth by taking interest or profit from the poor
    amasses it for another, who will be kind to the poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If anyone turns a deaf ear to my instruction,
    even their prayers are detestable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever leads the upright along an evil path
    will fall into their own trap,
    but the blameless will receive a good inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The rich are wise in their own eyes;
    one who is poor and discerning sees how deluded they are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the righteous triumph, there is great elation;
    but when the wicked rise to power, people go into hiding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever conceals their sins does not prosper,
    but the one who confesses and renounces them finds mercy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blessed is the one who always trembles before God,
    but whoever hardens their heart falls into trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a roaring lion or a charging bear
    is a wicked ruler over a helpless people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A tyrannical ruler practises extortion,
    but one who hates ill-gotten gain will enjoy a long reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The one whose way of life is blameless is kept safe,
    but the one whose ways are perverse will fall into the pit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who work their land will have abundant food,
    but those who chase fantasies will have their fill of poverty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A faithful person will be richly blessed,
    but one eager to get rich will not go unpunished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To show partiality is not good –
    yet a person will do wrong for a piece of bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The stingy are eager to get rich
    and are unaware that poverty awaits them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever rebukes a person will in the end gain favour
    rather than one who has a flattering tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever robs their father or mother
    and says, ‘It’s not wrong,’
    is partner to one who destroys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The greedy stir up conflict,
    but those who trust in the Lord will prosper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who trust in themselves are fools,
    but those who walk in wisdom are kept safe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who give to the poor will lack nothing,
    but those who close their eyes to them receive many curses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the wicked rise to power, people go into hiding;
    but when the wicked perish, the righteous thrive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever remains stiff-necked after many rebukes
    will suddenly be destroyed – without remedy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the righteous thrive, the people rejoice;
    when the wicked rule, the people groan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who loves wisdom brings joy to his father,
    but a companion of prostitutes squanders his wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By justice a king gives a country stability,
    but those who are greedy for bribes tear it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who flatter their neighbours
    are spreading nets for their feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Evildoers are snared by their own sin,
    but the righteous shout for joy and are glad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The righteous care about justice for the poor,
    but the wicked have no such concern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mockers stir up a city,
    but the wise turn away anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a wise person goes to court with a fool,
    the fool rages and scoffs, and there is no peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The bloodthirsty hate a person of integrity
    and seek to kill the upright.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fools give full vent to their rage,
    but the wise bring calm in the end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a ruler listens to lies,
    all his officials become wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The poor and the oppressor have this in common:
    the Lord gives sight to the eyes of both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a king judges the poor with fairness,
    his throne will be established for ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A rod and a reprimand impart wisdom,
    but a child left undisciplined disgraces its mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the wicked thrive, so does sin,
    but the righteous will see their downfall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Discipline your children, and they will give you peace;
    they will bring you the delights you desire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where there is no revelation, people cast off restraint;
    but blessed is the one who heeds wisdom’s instruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Servants cannot be corrected by mere words;
    though they understand, they will not respond.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you see someone who speaks in haste?
    There is more hope for a fool than for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A servant pampered from youth
    will turn out to be insolent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An angry person stirs up conflict,
    and a hot-tempered person commits many sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pride brings a person low,
    but the lowly in spirit gain honour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The accomplices of thieves are their own enemies;
    they are put under oath and dare not testify.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Fear of man will prove to be a snare,
    but whoever trusts in the Lord is kept safe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Many seek an audience with a ruler,
    but it is from the Lord that one gets justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The righteous detest the dishonest;
    the wicked detest the upright.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sayings of Agur son of Jakeh – an inspired utterance.
This man’s utterance to Ithiel:
‘I am weary, God,
    but I can prevail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely I am only a brute, not a man;
    I do not have human understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have not learned wisdom,
    nor have I attained to the knowledge of the Holy One.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has gone up to heaven and come down?
    Whose hands have gathered up the wind?
Who has wrapped up the waters in a cloak?
    Who has established all the ends of the earth?
What is his name, and what is the name of his son?
    Surely you know!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Every word of God is flawless;
    he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not add to his words,
    or he will rebuke you and prove you a liar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Two things I ask of you, Lord;
    do not refuse me before I die:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Otherwise, I may have too much and disown you
    and say, “Who is the Lord?”
Or I may become poor and steal,
    and so dishonour the name of my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Do not slander a servant to their master,
    or they will curse you, and you will pay for it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘There are those who curse their fathers
    and do not bless their mothers;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
those who are pure in their own eyes
    and yet are not cleansed of their filth;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
those whose eyes are ever so haughty,
    whose glances are so disdainful;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
those whose teeth are swords
    and whose jaws are set with knives
to devour the poor from the earth
    and the needy from among the human race.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘The leech has two daughters.
    “Give! Give!” they cry.
‘There are three things that are never satisfied,
    four that never say, “Enough!”:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the grave, the barren womb,
    land, which is never satisfied with water,
    and fire, which never says, “Enough!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘The eye that mocks a father,
    that scorns an aged mother,
will be pecked out by the ravens of the valley,
    will be eaten by the vultures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘There are three things that are too amazing for me,
    four that I do not understand:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the way of an eagle in the sky,
    the way of a snake on a rock,
the way of a ship on the high seas,
    and the way of a man with a young woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘This is the way of an adulterous woman:
    she eats and wipes her mouth
    and says, “I’ve done nothing wrong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Under three things the earth trembles,
    under four it cannot bear up:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a servant who becomes king,
    a godless fool who gets plenty to eat,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a contemptible woman who gets married,
    and a servant who displaces her mistress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Four things on earth are small,
    yet they are extremely wise:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
ants are creatures of little strength,
    yet they store up their food in the summer;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
hyraxes are creatures of little power,
    yet they make their home in the crags;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
locusts have no king,
    yet they advance together in ranks;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a lizard can be caught with the hand,
    yet it is found in kings’ palaces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘There are three things that are stately in their stride,
    four that move with stately bearing:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a lion, mighty among beasts,
    who retreats before nothing;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a strutting cock, a he-goat,
    and a king secure against revolt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘If you play the fool and exalt yourself,
    or if you plan evil,
    clap your hand over your mouth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For as churning cream produces butter,
    and as twisting the nose produces blood,
    so stirring up anger produces strife.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sayings of King Lemuel – an inspired utterance his mother taught him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, my son! Listen, son of my womb!
    Listen, my son, the answer to my prayers!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not spend your strength on women,
    your vigour on those who ruin kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is not for kings, Lemuel –
    it is not for kings to drink wine,
    not for rulers to crave beer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
lest they drink and forget what has been decreed,
    and deprive all the oppressed of their rights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let beer be for those who are perishing,
    wine for those who are in anguish!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let them drink and forget their poverty
    and remember their misery no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Speak up for those who cannot speak for themselves,
    for the rights of all who are destitute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Speak up and judge fairly;
    defend the rights of the poor and needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A wife of noble character who can find?
    She is worth far more than rubies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her husband has full confidence in her
    and lacks nothing of value.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She brings him good, not harm,
    all the days of her life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She selects wool and flax
    and works with eager hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is like the merchant ships,
    bringing her food from afar.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
She considers a field and buys it;
    out of her earnings she plants a vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She sets about her work vigorously;
    her arms are strong for her tasks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She sees that her trading is profitable,
    and her lamp does not go out at night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In her hand she holds the distaff
    and grasps the spindle with her fingers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She opens her arms to the poor
    and extends her hands to the needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When it snows, she has no fear for her household;
    for all of them are clothed in scarlet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She makes coverings for her bed;
    she is clothed in fine linen and purple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her husband is respected at the city gate,
    where he takes his seat among the elders of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She makes linen garments and sells them,
    and supplies the merchants with sashes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is clothed with strength and dignity;
    she can laugh at the days to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She speaks with wisdom,
    and faithful instruction is on her tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She watches over the affairs of her household
    and does not eat the bread of idleness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her children arise and call her blessed;
    her husband also, and he praises her:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Many women do noble things,
    but you surpass them all.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Charm is deceptive, and beauty is fleeting;
    but a woman who fears the Lord is to be praised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Honour her for all that her hands have done,
    and let her works bring her praise at the city gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator
